questions.text: The provision of 100% biodegradable sanitary napkins for Rs.1 per pad at Janaushadhi Kendras under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana is known as?
questions.solution:
Suvidha is the program aimed at the provision of 100% biodegradable sanitary napkins under Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana.

Low-cost hygienic oxy-biodegradable sanitary napkins were made available for Rs.1 per pad at over 7,900 Janaushadhi Kendras for the underprivileged women of India. The program aims to ensure ‘Swachhta, Swasthya, and Suvidha' for underprivileged women and to improve menstrual hygiene practices throughout the country.

Other options:

Option B: Freedays is the provision of a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees by the ASHA worker through the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme under the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK).

Option C: Saathiya is a government initiative launched to provide a platform for communication regarding adolescent age-related health issues. Saathiya, meaning a good friend, are peer educators trained by the government with the help of the Saathiya salah mobile application. These Saathiyas act as a catalyst for generating demand for adolescent health services and imparting age-appropriate knowledge on key adolescent health issues to their peer groups.

Option D: Sabla is an empowerment scheme for adolescent girls of age group 11 to 18 years to improve their nutritional and health status under the Integrated child development services scheme (ICDS).

questions.text: As a PHC medical officer, you learn that your region recorded an Annual parasite index (API) of 2.1. Which of the following measures would you take to ensure personal protection for the residents under the Integrated Vector Management (IVM) against malaria?

choices.text: No need for any measures as the district is a low risk area
Larvivorous fish and larvicides along with Long Lasting Insecticide Nets provision
Conventional insecticide treated bed nets are supplied
Long Lasting Insecticide Nets are provided

questions.solution:
Under the Integrated Vector Management initiative, conventional insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in endemic areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥2.

The annual parasite index (API) is used to categorize regions under the national framework for malaria elimination in India. API is based on the number of slide-confirmed cases that are found through active and passive surveillance. It is a measure of malaria incidence in a community and helps in determining the burden of the disease. Each district should stratify its PHCs and sub-centers (with their population) into the following five strata:

  1. Zero cases
  2. API > 0 to < 1
  3. API 1 to < 2
  4. API 2 to<5
  5. API 5

Regions with API ≥ 2 are considered high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control. Conventional insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in endemic areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥2. Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥5.

Integrated Vector Management (IVM) for Malaria Elimination:

For adult mosquitoes:

  • Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) are used as the main method of vector control in rural areas. DDT is the insecticide of choice.
  • Two rounds of spraying are done with DDT, and in DDT-resistant areas, three rounds of spraying are done with malathion.

For larvae: 

  • Larvivorous fish and larvicides are used. This is the main method of vector control in urban areas.

For personal protection: 

  • Insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in areas with API ≥2.
  • Long-Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with API ≥5.

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: Which component of the National AIDS Control Program does the image signify?

choices.text: PPTCT (Prevention of Parent To Child Transmission)

questions.solution:
The logo signifies Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission(PPTCT). The program was launched in 2002

Under this program pregnant women are provided with counselling and testing in the Integrated Counselling and Testing Centre (ICTC).

This program aims to prevent perinatal transmission of HIV from an infected pregnant mother to her newborn baby.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN)?
  1. It is a centrally sponsored scheme that provides one hot cooked meal in Government and Government-aided Schools
  2. It was previously known as Mid-Day Meal Scheme
  3. Provision of hot cooked meals only to preschool children
  4. Targets to reduce stunting, underweight, and low birth weight in children by 4% per annum.
  5. Targets to reduce anemia among young children by7% per annum
questions.solution:
Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN) previously known as Mid-Day Meal Scheme (Statement 2), is a centrally sponsored scheme that provides one hot cooked meal in Government and Government-aided Schools (Statement 1).

Under the Scheme, there is a provision of hot cooked meal to all preschool children and also to children of classes I to VIII (Statement 3). The scheme is implemented across the country covering all the eligible children without any discrimination of gender and social class. The main objective is to improve hunger and education by:

  • Providing hot-cooked meals in government and government-aided schools.
  • Attend school more regularly and concentrate on school activities.

Statements 4 and 5 are related targets under POSHAN Abhiyaan /National Nutrition Mission( NNM) which is different from Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN). 

Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) Abhiyaan is a flagship program of the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD), with a goal to achieve an improvement in the nutritional status of children in the first 1000 days of life, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. It targets to reduce stunting, underweight, and low birth weight by 2% per annum (Statement 4). The target for the reduction in anemia among young children (Statement 5), and adolescent girls is 3% per annum.

questions.text: Nischay kit provided by the government to ASHA under NRHM is used for?
questions.solution:
Nischay kit provided by the government to ASHA under NRHM is used for early pregnancy testing.

Nishchay is a home-based Pregnancy Test Kit (PTK) that was launched under NRHM across the country and was later anchored with the Family Planning Division. The pregnancy test kits are being made available at the sub-center level and are also distributed to ASHA.

These pregnancy test kits are supplied free of cost and are home-based and easy to use. It facilitates early detection and also decision-making for the outcomes of pregnancy. Helping to detect pregnancy as early as one week after the missed period, provides an early opportunity for medical termination of pregnancy, thus saving lives lost to unsafe abortions.

Note: NIKSHAY is an online tool launched by the government for RNTCP to monitor tuberculosis in the country.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the benefits under Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY)?

choices.text: It provides health insurance of upto Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year
No cap on family size and age of members
Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services

questions.solution:
Under Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), all pre-existing diseases are also covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.

Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), the largest health assurance scheme in the world which aims at providing a health cover of Rs. 5 lakhs per family per year for secondary and tertiary care across public and private empanelled hospitals in India, to over 12 crores poor and vulnerable families 

Benefits under the scheme:

  • The government provides health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year(Option B).
  • All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per the defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members (Option C).
  • Priority is given to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empaneled private hospitals in times of need.
  • It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,929 procedures covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, the cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • It covers up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days of post-hospitalization expenses such as diagnostics and medicines
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services (Option D).
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • A 24X7 helpline number is available for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances.

questions.text:
Which of the following measures are followed under NVBDCP (National vector-borne disease control program) to eliminate kala-azar?

1. Mosquito net

2. rK39 rapid diagnostic kits 

3. Mass immunization

4. Spraying pyrethroid

5. Insecticide-treated mosquito net
questions.solution:
Among the given options rK39 rapid diagnostic kits and spraying with insecticides such as pyrethroid are used to eliminate kala-azar under NVBDCP.

National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is a national health program that comes under the ministry of health and family welfare headed by the director-general of health services (DGHS). It works for the prevention and control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Malaria
  • Chikungunya
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Kala-azar 

Strategies for prevention and control of Kala-azar under NVBDCP:

  • Enhanced case detection through the introduction of rK39 rapid diagnostic kits (Statement 2)
  • Complete treatment by oral drug Miltefosine. 
  • Interruption of transmission through vector(sandfly) control by spraying/fogging with insecticides such as synthetic pyrethroid (Statement 4)
  • Incentives to:
    • ASHAs as Rs. 300 for identifying each case of kala-azar, Rs. 100 for ensuring one round, and Rs. 200 for two rounds of insecticide spraying. 
    • The patient being treated in the hospital as Rs. 500 for compensation of daily wage for the time he spends in the hospital during the treatment for kala-azar and Rs. 2,000 for PKDL.

Other options:

Statements 1 & 5: Distribution of mosquito nets is done to control mosquito-borne diseases and not kala-azar. Kala-azar is transmitted by the sand flies which are much smaller than mosquitoes and therefore can pass through smaller holes in the bed net.

Statement 3: There is no available vaccine for kala-azar and hence mass immunization is not used in the control of kala-azar.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: The Chest X-ray of a presumptive TB patient who presented with a dry cough and weight loss is suggestive of TB, but the sputum examination is negative. As per the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme guidelines, what should be the next step in management?

choices.text: Give antibiotics and repeat chest X-ray

questions.solution:
A patient with a suggestive CXR but sputum smear-negative should undergo a CB-NAAT as the next step in management.

CB NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) provides a rapid and accurate diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and mutations responsible for rifampicin resistance. It can be used for sputum samples as well as samples from extrapulmonary sites. It is done when the smear is negative for TB but the chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis and also in some cases smear is negative and the chest X-ray is not suggestive of TB but there is a high index of clinical suspicion.

It is mainly used for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB preferentially in the key population such as children, PLHIV, extra-pulmonary TB, and in smear-negative TB as per the diagnostic algorithm. 

Diagnostic algorithm for pulmonary TB:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: The given logo belongs to which of the following programmes?

choices.text: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the National Programme for Prevention & Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NP-NCD), which was earlier called the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

NPCDCS was launched in 2010 in order to prevent and control major NCDs (non-communicable diseases). It focuses on strengthening infrastructure, human resource development, health promotion, early diagnosis, management, and referral. NCD Clinics are being set up at District and CHC levels, to provide services for early diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up for common NCD. NP-NCD has specialized facilities at the district hospital level. At the subcentre level, screening and referral are done.

The NP-NCD has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states. For the cancer component, there is the Tertiary Care Cancer Centers (TCCC) scheme, which aims at setting up/strengthening State Cancer Institutes (SCI) and TCCCs all over the country, to provide comprehensive cancer care in the country. 

Note: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has been integrated with this programme in 2021.

Other options:

Option C: The logo below shows Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission

Option D: The logo below shows Family Planning Campaign

questions.text: As a PHC officer, you received blue color tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme. These tablets can be given to which of the following beneficiaries under this programme?
questions.solution:
Among the given beneficiaries, blue color tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid can be given to out-of-school adolescent girls according to the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme.

Blue color tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid can be given to school-going adolescent girls and boys of 10-19 years and out-of-school adolescent girls of age 10-19 years. Out-of-school adolescent boys are not beneficiaries of the scheme.

Children between 5-9 years of age (Option A)are given pink color sugar-coated tablets containing 45 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of folic acid tablets once a week.

Children of age 6-59 months are given bi-weekly syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg of folic acid. (Option C)

Lactating mothers of 0-6 month-old children (Option D) are given a daily dose of 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid. These tablets are sugar-coated and red in color.

The Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It focuses on six target beneficiary groups, through six interventions and six institutional mechanisms to achieve their target by 2022.

Interventions include:

  • Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication Campaign (Solid Body, Smart Mind) including ensuring delayed cord clamping in newborns.
  • Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of Iron and Folic Acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

questions.text: Which of the following is not included under the Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)?

choices.text: Free Transport between facilities in case of referral

questions.solution:
Free vaccination for newborns is not included under the Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK). The JSSK includes provisions for pregnant women and sick newborns till 30 days after birth. 

The JSSK provides free transport for pregnant women and sick infants from:

  • home to the health facilities
  • between facilities in case of a referral
  • back home from the health facilities

The provisions of JSSK include:

  • Free transport for pregnant women and sick infants
  • Free treatment for pregnant women and sick infants
  • Free drugs and consumables for pregnant women and sick infants
  • Free diagnostics for pregnant women and sick infants
  • Free diet provisions for pregnant women
  • Free and cashless delivery for pregnant women and sick infants
  • Free C-Section for pregnant women
  • Free provision of blood for pregnant women and sick infants

questions.text: A newly pregnant woman from a rural area registered in the scheme shown below. Which of the following benefits would she receive under this scheme?

choices.text: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 homebased newborn care visits
Free checkup on 9th of every month

questions.solution:
The above image shows the logo of Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA). Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month.

PMSMA aims to improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services. This is undertaken as part of the reproductive maternal neonatal child and adolescent health (RMNCH+A) strategy. Under PMSMA, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different colored stickers are given as follows:

  • Green sticker: For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red sticker: For women with detected risk factor

Other options:

Option A: A cash incentive of 5000 rupees is provided to all pregnant women and lactating mothers under Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY) for the first living child of the family. This is subject to fulfillment of specific conditions.

Option B: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits are provided under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative for women and newborns where assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare is provided free of cost.  It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.

Option D: A cash incentive of 1400 rupees is provided to all pregnant women who underwent an institutional delivery in low-performing states under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY). This scheme is launched under NRHM (national rural health mission) to promote institutional delivery.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not a component under the scheme shown in the logo below?
  1. Provision of preschool non-formal education
  2. Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram
  3. Kishori Shakti Yojana
  4. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram
  5. Nutrition programme for adolescent girls
questions.solution:
The logo in the above image is of the Integrated child development services scheme (ICDS). Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK)(Statement 2) and Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)(Statement 4) are interventions under the National Health Mission (NHM), not ICDS.

Integrated child development services was launched on the 2nd of October, 1975, and focuses on early childhood care and development. The scheme helps in providing preschool non-formal education (Statement 1) and breaking the vicious cycle of malnutrition, morbidity, reduced learning capacity, and mortality. Beneficiaries under the scheme include children in the age group of 0-6 years, pregnant women, and lactating mothers.

The Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) (Statement 3) and Nutrition Programme for Adolescent Girls (Statement 4) are two schemes for adolescent girls under ICDS.

Kishori Shakti Yojana targets adolescent girls in the age group of 11 to 18 years and addresses their needs of self-development, nutrition and health status, literacy and numerical skills, vocational skills, etc.

Nutrition Programme for Adolescent Girls targets undernourished adolescent girls in the age group of 11 to 19 years (with body weight less than 30 kg in the age group of 11 to 15 years and 35 kg in the age group of 15 to 19 years). 6 kg of free food grain is provided to each beneficiary per month.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK), an ambitious initiative, launched under the National Health Mission (NHM) launched envisages early screening and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years. It aims at the universal screening of the 4 ‘D’s, i.e. Defects at birth, Deficiencies, Diseases, Developmental delays, including disabilities, that would lead to early identification, timely management, and ultimately a reduction in morbidity, mortality, and lifelong disability in children.

Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) launched under NHM ensures holistic development of the adolescent population (10-19 years).

Related Pearl: Integrated child development services (ICDS)

Integrated child development services (ICDS): Package of services provided include:

  • Health check up

  • Health check up
  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Nutrition and health education

  • Nutrition and health education
Children <3 years
  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Immunization
  • Health check up
  • Referral services
Children 3-6 years of age
  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Immunization
  • Health check up
  • Referral services
  • Non formal education  
Adolescent girls 11 -18 years
  • Nutrition programme for adolescent girls

questions.text: During a rural health camp, a 21-year-old woman comes with a history of cough and breathlessness for a year. She gives a history of using firewood for cooking. No other significant co-morbidities were reported. You suspect the symptoms to be due to exposure to indoor pollution. Which among these initiatives, would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most relevant scheme for this patient experiencing the ill effects of using firewood for cooking would be the Ujjwala Yojana. 

The Ujjwala Yojana (note spelling without "a") is for providing 5 crore free cooking (LPG) connections to all families below the poverty line.

The UJALA Scheme (Unnat Jyoti by Affordable LEDs for All) is the largest domestic lighting project, launched under the Ministry of Power. It aims at promoting the use of energy-efficient LED bulbs in every household in the country.

The Ujjawala Scheme is for the prevention of trafficking and for the rescue, rehabilitation, and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.

INSPIRE strategy is a set of 7 evidence-based strategies introduced to select, implement, monitor, and evaluate effective policies, programs, and services to prevent and respond to violence against children.

questions.text: Which of these vaccines is not covered in the programme mentioned below?
questions.solution:
The given logo represents Mission Indradhanush and it does not include the typhoid vaccine.

Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush. The Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB (BCG vaccine)
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • Haemophilus influenzae B (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese encephalitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not an initiative under the Employees' state insurance (ESI) scheme?
questions.solution:
Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana is not an initiative under the Employees state insurance (ESI) scheme. It is a flagship social welfare program intended to provide housing for all in urban areas all over the India.

Abhiyan Indradhanush in relation to the ESI scheme refers to the change of bedsheets on a daily basis from Sunday to Saturday based on the VIBGYOR pattern for the color of the bedsheet.

Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana is an ESI scheme of unemployment allowance. As per this scheme, an insured person who becomes unemployed after being insured for three or more years, due to the closure of a factory/establishment, retrenchment, or permanent invalidity is entitled to:

  • Unemployment allowance equal to 50% of wage for a maximum period of up to 2 years.
  • Medical care for self and family from ESI hospitals/dispensaries during the period of unemployment allowance.
  • Vocational training provided for upgrading skills - expenditure on fee/traveling allowance borne by ESIC.

Extended sickness benefit is offered to insured people of the ESI scheme, who are suffering from certain chronic diseases, for a maximum period of 2 years, in addition to the 91 days of leave they are entitled to under the sickness benefit. During this period, they are paid about 80% of the average daily wages. The insured person should have been working for a continuous period of 2 years. There are 34 listed diseases for which the extended sickness benefit can be availed.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: A community health officer is assessing a healthcare facility under the scheme shown in the image below. Which of the following is the main objective of this scheme?

choices.text: To promote infection control practices in public health care facilities
To promote labor room quality and infrastructure
To provide physical aids and assisted-living devices for senior citizens
To improve the quality of care during the intrapartum and immediate postpartum period

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Kayakalp scheme. The main objective of the program is to promote cleanliness, hygiene, and infection control practices in public healthcare facilities. 

The Kayakalp scheme is a national initiative launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) under Swachh Bharat Abhiyan.

Other main objectives:

  • To incentivize and recognize public healthcare facilities that adhere to standard protocols of cleanliness and infection control
  • To instill a culture of ongoing assessment and review of performance related to hygiene, cleanliness, and sanitation
  • To create and share sustainable practices to improve cleanliness in public health facilities linked to positive health outcomes

Other options:

Option B- To promote labor room quality and infrastructure is the main objective of LaQshya, a program launched by the MoHFW. 

Option C- To provide physical aids and assisted-living devices for senior citizens belonging to the BPL category is the main objective of Rashtriya Vayoshri Yojana, a scheme by the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment.

Option D- To improve the quality of care for mothers and newborns during the intrapatum and immediate postpartum period by strengthening the competency of care providers is the main objective of Dakshata, a program launched by the MoHFW.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy comes from a remote village to the district hospital with multiple cuts and abrasions on his feet. He cannot remember how he acquired these wounds and does not feel any sensation in his foot. After addressing the wound, you provide him with Micro Cellular Rubber (MCR) footwear and advise him to follow up. What is the web-based system launched by the government that can help you track this patient?
questions.solution:
Nikusth is a real-time leprosy reporting software for monitoring leprosy patients with a patient tracking mechanism launched by the Health & Family Welfare Minister, Government of India.

Sparsh leprosy awareness campaign and the Nikusth system are related to Hansen's disease/leprosy.

"Sparsh Leprosy Awareness Campaign" (SLAC) was introduced in 2017 on the occasion of Anti-Leprosy day (observed on last Sunday of January) to promote awareness. NLEP introduced this campaign in order to address the issue of the high level of stigma attached to leprosy and to increase awareness about various aspects of leprosy.

Other options:

NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring of TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB)

Axshya is the project that works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

Note: 

Nikshay Poshan Yojana

Under Nikshay Poshan Yojana, a financial incentive of Rs. 500 per month is provided for nutritional support to each notified TB patient for the duration of anti-TB treatment. For pediatric TB patients who do not have bank accounts, the money shall be deposited in parent's/guardian's accounts whose details are to be sought and entered in Nikshay against the patient’s records. The processing of payment is on the 7th of every month.

Nishchay is a pregnancy test kit introduced by the government.

questions.text: You are working at an NGO eye hospital which provides affordable eye-care to people in need. Under the program whose logo is given below, NGO eye hospitals are considered ____________
questions.solution:
Under the National Programme for the Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI), whose logo is shown above, NGO eye hospitals are considered secondary level.

The levels of eye care, according to NPCBVI are:

  • Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centers, mobile ophthalmic units, upgraded PHCs, link workers, Panchayats.
  • Secondary level: District hospitals, NGO eye hospitals
  • Tertiary levels: Regional institutes of Ophthalmology, medical colleges.
